title: 108_hr4415
content: The Act may be cited as the "Save American Jobs Through L Visa Reform Act of 2004". The Congress finds widespread abuse by companies subcontracting nonimmigrants who obtained status under the Immigration and Nationality Act as intracompany transferees with specialized knowledge. This abuse includes displacing US citizens from their jobs and terminating their employment after training the nonimmigrants. Employers have abused the intracompany transferee visa program by admitting individuals without the required "specialized knowledge," flooding the job market and displacing US citizens from their jobs. In China, there is a high rate of fraud in intracompany transferee nonimmigrant visa petitions, with a reported fraud rate of about 40 percent since fiscal year 2000. Similar fraud rates have been reported in other areas of China as well. SEC. 3. Amendment to eliminate nonimmigrant visas for intracompany transferees with specialized knowledge, limiting admission period to 7 years. Conforming amendments made to Immigration and Nationality Act. SEC. 4. Imposition of annual numerical limitation. SEC. 4. Imposition of annual numerical limitation on intracompany transferee visas to 35,000 per fiscal year starting from 2005. Spouses and children not included in the limit. Section 214(b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to specify the payment of prevailing wages for nonimmigrants under section 101(a)(15)(L). Employers should pay these nonimmigrants wages that are at least the greater of the actual wage level paid to others with similar experience or the prevailing wage level for the occupation. Effective date is specified. The amendments made by this Act regarding nonimmigrant visas under section 101(a)(15)(L) of the Immigration and Nationality Act will take effect on the enactment date. Any visas issued before this date will not be affected by the amendment.
